post_html:
As a recruiter, I view resumes fairly often ğŸ˜‹

Hehe, if I can, just a few tips and ideas for those on the employment search?
(I am by no means a PRO, this purely my opinion from patterns I and my team see.)

And by all means, ignore everything I say... we enjoy a good laugh ğŸ˜ğŸ˜
hashtag#diabolical

Honestly, I would like to spend more time talking with YOU rather than asking about all the gaps or confusion that comes from unfinished or empty resumes.
(I hope this finds the right audience ğŸ˜¬!)

So...

1. INTRO - We love an intro! Every Indeed manufactured resume looks generic with the "will relocate anywhere" which, frankly, isn't true.
Tell me about you and what your goal is in seeking a new position! This helps me get a head start when I get a blurb about what you want and where you are at in your search.

2. DATES - For the love of all things holy and good and...
Clean up your dates, don't leave gaps, and explain temp, contract, or seasonal jobs. We automatically rule out poor job longevity so if you explain the reason behind short-term positions, boom!

3. CONTEXT - Give me context please! Who are you?!
Whether you work at a Warehouse, in Construction, or got involved in Manufacturing... it seems that unless you are OCD, most of the time there is a LACK of information on what you actually did on your resume. Keep in mind- sometimes title doesn't match responsibilities. Add leadership skills and certificates to your timeline so we can really see what you have to offer!

4. ERRORS- *clears throat. We pay attention to spelling and grammar errors. I mean, we're here to help update all that for your future employer, but if you catch it, make the change! This includes resume gaps that we want to understand AND inconsistency in punctuation, font, and bullet points.
Take a second to review before uploading.

5. SKILLS - Don't let a resume generator do all the work! I want to know what YOU specifically can do and that is not always given proper honor when you allow a hiring site to guess your skills based on your previous roles. Really think about what you have accrued besides the typical additions of "time management" and "customer service." We know you have more to offer!

Just a few thoughts! We would love to give you and your future employer the BEST CHANCE in connecting.

The design, layout, and content of your resume are essential for capturing the reader's attention in the first 20 to 30 seconds. Itâ€™s important to approach this task with a clear strategy, focusing on highlighting your skills and experience in a concise and engaging way. Here are a few tips to help you craft the perfect resume:

1. Highlight your accomplishments: If you cut costs, increased revenue, delivered projects ahead of time, or broke company records, your resume is the perfect place to highlight these achievements using numbers and percentages to demonstrate your impact.
2. Call out the value you would bring to the target company: Just like in sports, where the value of a new player is debated, your resume is the place to highlight the value you can bring to a potential employer, using the language that aligns with the job you're applying for.
3. Identify the ways you help solve the companyâ€™s challenges: Just like an infomercial highlights a productâ€™s strengths to solve a problem, your resume should showcase your professional assets and demonstrate how you can address the challenges of the company you're applying to.

The right job for you is out there. We can help get you to it

Is your resume starting to resemble a novel? ğŸ“š Let's trim that epic down to a compelling short story!

Here's how:
1. Prioritize the Last 10-15 Years: Focus on your most recent experience; hiring managers are more interested in what you've done lately.
2. Highlight Achievements, Not Just Duties: Showcase your impact with quantifiable resultsâ€”think revenue growth, cost savings, or process improvements.
3. Remove Outdated Skills: If it's no longer relevant (e.g., obsolete software), leave it out.
4. Use a Hybrid Resume Format: A skills-focused format helps showcase expertise before listing work history.
5. Tailor for Each Job: Only include roles that are directly relevant.
Remember, your resume should be a highlight reel, not a documentary. Keep it concise, relevant, and future-focused to show why you're the best fit for today's job market.

What's your biggest challenge in keeping your resume concise? Let's discuss in the comments!

hashtag#ResumeTips hashtag#CareerDevelopment hashtag#JobSearch hashtag#ProfessionalGrowth hashtag#InterviewTips

Resume making tips for an impressive and impactful resume.

Tips for Writing an ATS-Friendly Resume:

Use Standard Headings: Stick to common headings like "Work Experience," "Education," and "Skills."

Keep Formatting Simple: Avoid complex layouts, tables, and graphics that might confuse ATS.

Incorporate Keywords: Use job-specific keywords from the job description to ensure your resume matches the job requirements.

Use a Professional Font: Stick to fonts like Arial, Times New Roman, or Calibri to ensure readability.

I hear so many engineers asking about ATS-friendly resumes, so I am going to break it down for you today!

Let's use these tips for writing an ATS-friendly resume:
âœ… Use standard headings:
 - Stick to common headings like â€œWork Experience,â€ â€œEducation,â€ & "Skills.â€

âœ… Keep formatting simple:
 - Avoid complex layouts, tables, and graphics that could confuse ATS systems.

âœ… Incorporate keywords:
 - Strategically incorporate relevant keywords from the job description to ensure your resume matches the job requirements.
- Try to match 70-80% of job description language

âœ… Use a professional & readable font:
 -  Stick to fonts like Arial, Times New Roman, or Calibri to ensure readability.

âœ… Tailor each resume:
 - Customize your resume for each job application to reflect the specific job requirements.

âœ… Quantify relevant experiences:
 - Highlight measurable achievements and impactful projects.

Critical resume mistakes to avoid:

âŒ Omit personal details:
 - Do not include details like age, marital status, or photographs.

âŒ Avoid complex designs:
 - Skip colourful, overly creative layouts that distract from the main content.

âŒ Exclude irrelevant experiences:
 - Focus only on relevant, recent experience to keep your resume concise.

âŒ Keep graduate resumes short:
 - For fresh graduates, limit your resume to one page.
Your resume is your first impression, make sure it is clear, optimized, and ATS-friendly to increase your chances of landing an interview.

âœ… Focus on readability, relevance, and measurable impact.
âœ… Use relevant keywords from the job description.
âœ… Keep formatting clean and simple (avoid graphics/tables).
âœ… Tailor each resume for the role, one-size-fits-all wonâ€™t work.
âœ… Want better results? Apply online AND network with hiring managers!

Finally,
ğŸ‘‰ An ATS-friendly resume doesnâ€™t just pass the ATS, it gets you noticed by recruiters!
ğŸ‘‰ ATS is just a tool, it doesnâ€™t make hiring decisions!
ğŸ‘‰ ATS is not your enemy, it is a tool that helps recruiters.
ğŸ‘‰ Stop fearing it and focus on what you can control
ğŸ‘‰ Make your resume work for you!

Earning the trust of hiring managers is a steep mountain to climb, yet one that holds the key to effective hashtag#recruitment. As someone who's been in the thick of it for years, I've navigated this climb and gathered invaluable insights.

Today, I want to share these time-tested tips to help you win over even the toughest of hiring managers:

1. Cultivate a partner mindset ğŸ¤: First things first, you're not just a recruiter, but a strategic partner. Think about it. It's not just about filling a role; it's about understanding the unique requirements of a position, recognizing the team dynamic, and finding a person who fits like a glove.

2. Keep communication clear and consistent ğŸ’¬: You've heard it before, and I'll say it again. Communication is key. Consistently update your hiring manager about the progress you're making, potential hiccups in the pipeline, and candidate feedback. Trust me, they'll appreciate your transparency.

3. Demonstrate market knowledge ğŸ“‘: Show them you know your stuff. Keep abreast of industry trends, shifts in the job market, and salary benchmarks. Knowledge is power, and in this case, it can be the bridge to trust.

4. Go beyond the resume ğŸ“ƒ: When you're presenting a candidate, don't just forward a hashtag#resume. Instead, present a comprehensive view of the candidate's skills, experience, and cultural fit. Highlight why you believe they're right for the job. It's all about the details.

Keep these nuggets in your arsenal, and you'll be a hiring manager's dream in no time!

hashtag#recruitcrm hashtag#recruitmenttips hashtag#hiringtips hashtag#hiringmanagers hashtag#trustbuilding

post_html:
Want to stand out in today's job market? You absolutely need to try these TOTALLY not terrible tips.


Forget the usual advice.

People will try and tell you to tailor your resume for each job, build your network, optimize your LinkedIn profile....blah blah blah.

We all know that doesn't work.

If you REALLY want to grab a recruiter's attention, here's what DEFINTIELY works:

1. Make your resume as long as it needs to be!

Have 20 years of experience?

Document everything and make your resume 12 pages long!

Nothing says "Top candidate" like making recruiters work hard to find the important information.

Bonus points if you use size 8 font for your entire resume!

2. Apply to the same job 37 times!

They'll have to notice you eventually right?

Persistence? Yes.

Stalking? That's for you to decide.

3. Make sure your LinkedIn photo is a selfie from the club!

Employers LOVE a candidate who is the life of the party.

It's great for the culture!

4. Slide into a recruiter's DM's at 2AM and ask for an update on your application.

It's well-timed and will help you stand out because you have a better chance of being noticed as the only person to message them when they are trying to sleep!

I could offer more (great) job searching advice but I don't want to "spill all the tea" in one post.

Do you have any other "great" career advice tips that you would like to share?

Let me know in the comments!

Have a great Saturday everyone!

hashtag#jobsearch hashtag#careertips hashtag#humor hashtag#smile hashtag#jobseekers hashtag#standouttherightway

ğŸ•’ How I Review 100 Resumes in Under an Hour

Ever felt buried under a mountain of resumes? Itâ€™s easy to get overwhelmed, but thereâ€™s a faster, smarter way to sift through the noise and find the top talent. Hereâ€™s how I break it down:

1ï¸âƒ£ Prioritize must-have skills: Start with non-negotiables. If the role requires Python or AWS experience, filter for it upfront.

2ï¸âƒ£ Scan for relevant projects: Look for real-world examples where candidates contributed to projects similar to what you need.

3ï¸âƒ£ Check for career progression: Promotions, increased responsibility, and diverse roles show growth and initiative.

4ï¸âƒ£ Use keyword searches: Boolean search is your friend! Combine terms like â€œDevOps AND CI/CDâ€ to narrow the pool.

5ï¸âƒ£ Pre-set scorecards: Create a scoring system to stay objective. Rate candidates based on skills, experience, and key achievements. No more gut-feeling decisions!

âš¡ Pro Tip: Batch your review timeâ€”30 focused minutes beats hours of multitasking any day.

Need a breakdown of any of these steps? Let me know!ğŸ‘‡

Want to write a resume that passes all the tests? Then, you need to follow our best tips for a successful resume:

1. Add contact info
Start your hashtag#resume by listing down your name and contact information. Itâ€™s important to check the spelling for typos.

2. Write a summary
A professional summary that highlights your biggest selling points must go on at the top of your hashtag#resume to impress readers.

3. Add work experience
Limit your work experience to the most recent and relevant jobs so that you align with the requirements of the employer.

4. Highlight education
Educational qualifications are a must-have for your hashtag#resume. Be sure to list your education on your resume.

5. Add the skills
Now, it is time for you to create a dedicated key skills section that displays all the right key skills on your hashtag#resume.

The secret to landing that dream job? It's so simple.

NEVER USE PDFs FOR YOUR RESUME. Too easy for your prospective hiring manager to open. Make them work for it. Use a weird format like .BMP or .Tiff. This provides an air of mystery to your resume. "What could this be? How the hell do I even open a TARGA file in 2025?" Hiring managers love puzzle solving, so give them something they can really sink their teeth into.

START INTERVIEWS BY REVEALING A TRAGIC FAMILY SECRET: You can make one up if you need to. "My grandpa could have stopped Ted Bundy, but didn't" is a good one. "Every one of my uncles is a horse thief" is more niche, but there's a timeless quality to it. My tip? Have fun with it.

INSIST ON BEING PAID IN RARE JEWELS: Inflation, shmilflation! Sure, it may take a few extra steps, but nothing spends better than a sack full of sapphires, emeralds, and diamonds. Slapping down a topaz at the local five and dime is a real flex.

FORCE YOUR INTERVIEWER TO TAKE A POSITION ON MARTIN LUTHER: Divinely inspired reformer, or blasphemous oaf? Both positions are respectable, but make them take a side, and more importantly, defend it.

END WITH A SONG: Most interviewers end interviews with "Do you have any more questions?" This is when you queue up some music and say, "Just one: do you enjoy Billy Joel's middle period?" That's when you can delight them with a rendition of "Uptown Girl" or "Allentown." Don't go for B-Sides like "Big Man on Mulberry Street" or "Running on Ice" you'll just be wasting everyone's time.

Hope this helps! Feel free to leave your favorite job-landing tip below!

âœ¨ğŸ“„ Resume Building 101: Stand Out in 20 Seconds ğŸ“„âœ¨
Did you know that employers typically spend only 20 to 30 seconds looking at a resume? Make every second count with these top tips:
1. Choose the Right Format: Highlight your experiences, skills, and abilities in a format that suits you best. A reverse chronological order is often effective, listing your most recent activities first.
2. Keep It Concise: Aim for a one-page resume with consistent formatting. Use bullet points and simple sentences for clarity.
3. Be Honest: Always be truthful. Employers verify information, and honesty is key.
4. Visual Appeal: Make your resume visually appealing to grab attention.
5. Tailor Your Resume: Customize your resume for each job application. Highlight relevant skills and experiences.
6. Clear Objective: Include a clear resume objective to give employers insight into your interests.
7. Action Verbs: Start sentences with powerful action verbs to make your points impactful.
8. Error-Free: Ensure your resume is free of grammatical, spelling, punctuation, and typographical errors.
9. Use Keywords: Incorporate industry-specific keywords and phrases to make your resume relevant to recruiters. For example, if you're an Accounting major, include 'CPA Eligible by May 2025'.
10. Show Leadership and Achievements: Highlight any leadership roles, achievements, and organizational involvement. Make sure these are also visible on your LinkedIn profile.
Remember, a well-crafted resume can make a significant difference in your job application process. Let's make your resume shine! ğŸŒŸ

The Truth Behind 6 Resume Myths ğŸ”Š

Thereâ€™s a lot of resume â€œwisdomâ€ floating around the internetâ€”but not all of it is accurate. Letâ€™s bust six of the most common resume myths and set the record straight:

1. Your Resume Must Be One Page
Not true! If you have substantial experience, itâ€™s okay to go up to two pages. What matters is how relevant and concise your content is.

2. Gaps in Your Resume Are Dealbreakers
Life happens! As long as you address gaps confidently and show how you stayed active or grew during them, it wonâ€™t sink your chances.

3. You Always Need References
Nope! Employers typically ask for references after youâ€™ve made it through the initial stages. Keep them on hand but off your resume.

4. Your Resume Should Be "Unique"
A flashy, one-of-a-kind resume isnâ€™t necessary unless youâ€™re in a creative field. Focus on clarity and relevance instead of gimmicks.

5. You Have to List Your Full Address
The days of snail mail are over! Just list your city and stateâ€”no need for your full address.

6. Dates and Employer Names Arenâ€™t Important
Think again! Hiring managers want to know where you worked and for how long. Dates and employer names give your experience credibility.

8 Essential Skills to Highlight on Your Resume


Enhance your resume by highlighting these essential skills and utilizing tools like :
https://lnkd.in/ga_CyE_7


In todayâ€™s competitive job market, showcasing the right skills on your resume is crucial to stand out to employers. Here are eight essential skills you should highlight:

1. Communication
Clearly convey ideas through writing and speaking.

2. Problem-Solving
Identify issues and develop effective solutions.

3. Technical Proficiency
Master relevant software and tools in your field.

4. Teamwork
Collaborate effectively with colleagues.

5. Leadership
Lead projects and guide team members.

6. Adaptability
Adjust to changing environments and challenges.

7. Time Management
Prioritize tasks to meet deadlines efficiently.

8. Critical Thinking
Analyze situations to make informed decisions.






---
Resume Tips and Tricks

- Tailor Your Resume: Customize it for each job to highlight relevant skills.
- Use Action Verbs: Start bullet points with strong verbs like "led" or "developed."
- Quantify Achievements: Include numbers to showcase your impact.
- Keep It Concise: Limit to one or two pages with clear information.
- Proofread: Ensure your resume is error-free.
- Highlight Soft Skills: Emphasize teamwork and adaptability.
- Include a Summary: Provide a brief overview of your qualifications.
- Clean Layout: Use organized sections and consistent formatting.


Follow these tips to create a standout resume that attracts employers and advances your career.

5 Important Resume Writing Tips for Freshers ğŸ¤—

Creating a resume as a fresher can be intimidating, but itâ€™s your chance to make a strong first impression. Hereâ€™s how to make sure your resume stands out:

1. Stick to a Proper Format
Your resume should have clear sections like summary, education, skills, and relevant experience. Structure is key!

2. Get to the Point
Donâ€™t rambleâ€”employers appreciate clarity. Give them as much relevant info as possible in a concise format.

3. Mirror the Companyâ€™s Language
Use professional language, and echo key phrases from the job description or the companyâ€™s website. It shows you did your homework.

4. Tailor It to Each Job

Most people donâ€™t know how to use ChatGPT for job search.

But it doesn't have to be that way.

Here are 10 ChatGPT resume prompts to land your dream job:

Role-specific Resumes:

"You are Resume GPT, an expert in crafting industry-specific resumes. Using the input {job_title} and {skills}, create a resume tailored for this role. Ensure it aligns with {industry_standards}, emphasizing {achievements} and {keywords}."

Resume Revamp:

"Take this resume: {resume_content} and improve it for {job_title}. Focus on clarity, strong action verbs, quantifiable achievements, and ATS optimization. Highlight transferable skills if applicable."

Resume from Scratch:

"Generate a professional resume for {job_title} based on the following: {experience}, {education}, {skills}, and {certifications}. Ensure it includes a strong summary and action-driven bullet points."

Highlight Achievements:

"Using {job_title} and {achievements}, craft three strong bullet points showcasing impactful results. Use metrics and action verbs, ensuring relevance to {industry}."

Career Switch Focus:

"Help rewrite a resume for a career switcher moving from {current_role} to {desired_role}. Emphasize transferable skills, achievements, and soft skills relevant to the new role."

Formatting Optimization:

"Review this resume content: {resume_content} and reformat it for clarity and professionalism. Ensure optimal use of {layout_style} and proper alignment with {ATS} standards."

Objective Statement Writing:

"Write a compelling resume objective for someone seeking a {job_title} role. The focus is on {goals}, {skills}, and {industry expertise} to grab recruiters' attention."

Entry-level Resumes:

"Create a resume for an entry-level candidate with the following: {education}, {internships}, {skills}, and {projects}. Highlight achievements in coursework or extracurriculars."

Executive Resume:

"Develop an executive-level resume for {job_title} with an emphasis on {leadership}, {strategic impact}, and {revenue growth}. Use concise language and quantified accomplishments."

Cover Letter Pairing:

"Pair this resume {resume_content} with a tailored cover letter for {job_title}. Highlight {key_achievements}, why {company_name} is appealing, and how the candidate's skills meet {job_requirements}."

Thanks for checking...

post_html:
Building Your Resume ,the basics for the Undergrads

Key Elements
1.   Correct and Concise Information
 o Ensure all information is accurate.
 o Keep descriptions brief and to the point.
2.   Clear Font and Format
 o Use easy-to-read fonts (e.g., Arial, Calibri).
 o Maintain consistent formatting (headings, bullet points).
3.   Showcase Skills
 o Highlight relevant skills at the top.
 o Use a mix of hard and soft skills.
4.   Project Achievements
 o Include specific examples of projects.
 o Use metrics to quantify achievements (e.g., â€œIncreased sales by 20%â€).
5.   Sight on Keywords
 o Use keywords from the job description.
 o Incorporate industry-specific terms.
6.   Efforts and Experience
 o Detail your work experience clearly.
 o Focus on responsibilities and contributions.

Before You Apply for a Job
1.   Research About the Company
 o Understand the companyâ€™s mission and values.
 o Familiarize yourself with their products/services.
2.   Update Resume
 o Tailor your resume for each job application.
 o Add any new skills or experiences.
3.   Align Skills with Job Roles
 o Highlight skills that match the job description.
 o Use examples that demonstrate those skills.
4.   Read Job Description Well
 o Identify key responsibilities and requirements.
 o  Ensure your resume addresses these points.
Additional Tips
Â·      Proofread: Check for grammatical errors and typos.
Â·      Keep it Relevant: Focus on experiences that relate to the job.
Â·      Use Action Verbs: Start bullet points with strong action verbs (e.g., "Developed," "Led," "Implemented").

6 resume tips for school leavers

Are you about to craft your very first resume as a school leaver? This is a crucial step in starting off your career journey right, and we are right here to help you with it:

1. Highlight your education
Since you likely have less work experience, you need to make your education the focus of your hashtag#resume.

2. Highlight relevant skills
You will develop many job-related skills and transferable skills in your college years. Incorporate them into your hashtag#resume.

3. Talk about extracurricular activities
You can bring out important skills like teamwork, organization, and leadership on your hashtag#resume through extracurricular activities.

4. Write a good summary
The summary statement is an important element of your hashtag#resume. Donâ€™t skip writing it.

5. Create a clean format
Donâ€™t overcrowd your resume with design elements. Keep your hashtag#resume format clean and easy to read.

6. Proofread the document
You canâ€™t afford to make mistakes on your hashtag#resume. Proofread the document before you send it out to employers.

post_html:
6 pieces of career advice for recent grads

1. Donâ€™t settle for the first offer
Take time to assess job offers and choose roles that align with your long-term goals.

2. Build your network early
Attend networking events, connect with alumni, and stay active on LinkedIn. Relationships can open doors to opportunities.

3. Focus on learning
Seek roles that offer mentorship, skill-building, and growth opportunities, even if the pay isnâ€™t top-notch initially.

4. Be adaptable
Careers rarely follow a straight path. Embrace unexpected opportunities and learn from every experience.

5. Ask for feedback
Constructive criticism helps you grow. Actively seek feedback from supervisors and colleagues.

6. Keep upskilling
Stay competitive by continually learning new skills or earning certifications relevant to your field.

Another lesson learned from responses I've received to "no thank you" emails sent to applicants: I occasionally get responses from applicants pointing out how relevant their experience is--experience not apparent in their resume. Candidates, make it easy on both sides:

* Customize your resume for every job you apply for.
* Look at the skills, responsibilities, and experience in the job posting and then make sure as many of those as possible are explicitly stated in your resume (within the bounds of truth, of course).
* Use easy-to-skim bullets. Don't make a recruiter squint through long paragraphs trying to understand your value.
* Don't assume that a recruiter understands what your previous roles have involved. If you're applying for a job that requires phone skills, for example, spell out in your resume how you've used phone skills in previous roles.

Doing the above helps a recruiter quickly see your relevance to their job and boosts your chances of getting an interview. A win for all!

hashtag#jobsearchtips hashtag#jobsearch hashtag#jobapplication
Elizabeth Monroe Katrina Whitehair, MBA

hashtag#jobseekerprotips

ğŸ˜ There are no perfect resumes, nor situations, but here are some quick general tips that will increase your odds of interviews and offers:

-Make sure your LinkedIn link on your resume works.
-Make sure your phone number has no typos.
-Make sure your email link actually goes to your email/works, no typos.
-If you use multiple phone numbers or email addresses, only put one on the resume. Confusion isn't a great way to start a relationship and making someone have to look for you isn't either.
-Actually, monitor the voicemail, text, inbox, and spam box to the phone and email listed on your resume.
-Use STAR/CARL interview methods in communication. Do not overtalk the recruiters, HR, panelists, hiring manager, etc.
-Follow-up, but don't oversell/over pursue. There has to be balance.

If you liked these, hit share, and follow for more tips in the future.

Why is your resume not getting the attention it deserves in a pile of hundreds? Could it be that it's not telling your unique story effectively?

A resume is more than just a list of job titles and duties.

Itâ€™s a marketing document that should sell your personal brand.

Each line should be purposeful and demonstrate value.

So, what makes a resume stand out in a sea of competitors?

Consider including quantifiable achievements rather than vague responsibilities.

Numbers convey impact and help employers visualize your contributions.

Have you customized it to your target role?

A one-size-fits-all approach could dilute your message and lessen your chances.

Taking the time to tailor your skills and experiences to align with the job description can make all the difference.

Have you had a friend or mentor review it for clarity?

Fresh eyes can catch errors you might have missed and offer new perspectives.

How do you ensure your resume leaves a memorable impression?

ğŸŒŸ Boost Your Job Search with the Power of High-Quality Recommendations ğŸŒŸ

In a competitive job market, one of the most effective ways to get your resume noticed is through your network and their recommendations. A well-timed and thoughtful recommendation can make all the difference.

Hereâ€™s how you can leverage this to your advantage:

1. Give Your Connections a Heads-Up â€“ If you're planning to mention someone in an interview, let them know in advance. This allows them to be prepared to offer a strong, up-to-date recommendation that highlights your strengths. No one likes to be caught off guard, and you'll get a much stronger, tailored recommendation in return.

2. Be Proactive in Supporting Others â€“ If you recommend someone to a recruiter or headhunter, make sure to tell them! Why? It adds real value to the recruiter's message and strengthens your relationship for future recommendations.

3. Reach Out to An Employee for â˜• - Over the years, I have had networking coffees and virtual chats that have grown into referrals and job opportunities.

Remember, building strong, supportive relationships within your network isnâ€™t just about what others can do for you â€” itâ€™s about mutual support and helping one another thrive.

Planning to change careers soon? Then, you need a strong resume to help you find a great opportunity, fast. Here are some of our best tips to navigate a career transition:

1. Identify transferable skills
Transferable skills help you emphasize knowledge areas that apply across industries and roles on your hashtag#resume.

2. Address employment gaps
It is normal to have one or two short gaps on your hashtag#resume. List your career gaps upfront and provide brief explanations for them.

3. Reframe your experience
Even if your past roles arenâ€™t related to the new job, you can present them on your hashtag#resume in such a way that they are relevant to the new scope.

4. Add new skills
Have you upskilled yourself for your career transition? Then, your new hashtag#resume must showcase your new skills and qualifications.

5. Highlight certifications
If you are transitioning into a field that requires you to be certified to practice, such as accounting, healthcare, or beauty, you should add your new certifications to your hashtag#resume.

post_html:
If a portfolio opens the doors, a resume is the key.

Even if recruiters spend 3 seconds reading it,
don't neglect it.

It's most likely the first point of contact.
Your first impression.
Don't make it the last one.

As design is primarily a visual discipline,
you focus most of your attention on the portfolio.
That makes sense, but if you neglect your resume,
your portfolio might never be seen.

Here's the list of things to consider when working on a resume.

â€¢ Ensure proper metadata in the PDF properties
â€¢ Use vector formats for any icons or graphics
â€¢ Keep the document resolution at 300 DPI
â€¢ Test the resume's readability in grayscale
â€¢ Don't use Figma for ATS-compatible resumes
â€¢ Check contrast ratios meet WCAG AA standards at minimum
â†“ more of them in the attached doc.

âœŒï¸

P.S. What is your favorite tip for resumes?

post_html:
Reassessing Resume Gaps: A Shift in Perspective

To Employers:
When evaluating candidates, it's crucial to look beyond resume gaps and recognize the inherent value they may bring. Inspired by HBR, consider these tips for assessing career breaks:
- Inquire about the story behind the gap to uncover valuable skills, resilience, or renewed direction.
- Emphasize growth over gaps, acknowledging how candidates use this time to upskill, volunteer, or reflect on their career trajectory.
- Acknowledge the evolving norm of career breaks post-pandemic, understanding its impact on workers' priorities.
- Value authenticity in candidates who address gaps with honesty and confidence, traits they may bring to your team.

Remember, a resume gap signifies more than a pauseâ€”it often symbolizes a period of growth, learning, or life management. Keeping an open mind could lead you to your next exceptional hire.

To Job Seekers:
- Address resume gaps directly, focusing on the positive aspects and how they enriched your life or skills.
- Highlight personal growth during the gap, showcasing volunteer work, new skills acquired, or realigned goals.
- Tailor your explanation to the role, emphasizing how your experiences strengthen your candidacy.
- Confidently own your unique career journey, understanding that a gap doesn't define you; it's how you navigate and learn from it that matters.

Have you considered the untapped potential of resume gaps? Individuals with extended breaks have secured remarkable roles by leveraging their distinctive strengths and experiences. Share your insights on uncovering the value within these gaps below!

post_html:
The painful truth about ATS "hacks" that no one's talking about...

I see job seekers spending countless hours:
âœ”ï¸ Cramming keywords
âœ”ï¸ Using white text
âœ”ï¸ Creating complex tables
âœ”ï¸ Testing "perfect" formatting tricks

Here's the reality: Modern ATS systems are FAR more sophisticated than you think. Those outdated hacks from 2015? They might actually be hurting your chances.

Instead, focus on what truly matters:

Write for humans first, ATS second The hiring manager needs to WANT to read your resume. Clear, compelling achievements beat keyword stuffing every time.

Use clean, standard formatting Simple beats clever. Period. Your beautifully formatted resume means nothing if it's unreadable to human eyes.

Tailor with intention Don't just mirror job descriptions. Understand the role's core needs and demonstrate your relevant impact.

Remember: The goal isn't to "beat" the ATS. It's to reach the hiring manager's desk with a resume that makes them want to meet you.

Pro tip: Want to test your resume? Send it to yourself as a plain text file. If it's readable there, most ATS systems will handle it just fine.

Want to check your resume's ATS score? Drop "Score" in the comments - I'll carryout a free ATS scan on your resume and share the result with you.

Repost for someone who needs to hear this and follow Seun Ige for more of this

Land Your Dream Job with These Essential Resume Tips

Your resume is the first impression you make on recruiters, itâ€™s your ticket to standing out in a competitive job market. Crafting a standout resume takes effort, but with the right approach, you can make it unforgettable. Here are some top tips to ensure your resume gets noticed:

1ï¸âƒ£ Tailor Your Resume to the Job
ğŸ¯ Why it matters: Generic resumes donâ€™t impress.
Customize your resume for each role by aligning it with the job description.
Highlight the skills and experiences that are most relevant to the position.

2ï¸âƒ£ Highlight Relevant Experience
ğŸ’¼ Why it matters: Recruiters focus on whatâ€™s applicable to the job.
Showcase experiences that align with the role.
For unrelated roles, reframe your experience to demonstrate transferable skills.

3ï¸âƒ£ Keep It Short
ğŸ“ Why it matters: Less is more in resume writing.
Aim for a one- or two-page resume.
Focus on concise, impactful descriptions of your skills and achievements.

4ï¸âƒ£ Use Action Verbs
ğŸ’ª Why it matters: Dynamic language grabs attention.
Begin bullet points with action verbs like "led," "improved," "created," or "streamlined."
Action verbs also help you stand out to Applicant Tracking Systems (ATS).

5ï¸âƒ£ Choose the Right Format
ğŸ“‚ Why it matters: Your format reflects your career goals.
Pick a chronological format for steady work history.
Opt for a functional or hybrid format if youâ€™re changing careers or highlighting skills.

6ï¸âƒ£ Add Numbers
ğŸ”¢ Why it matters: Metrics make your accomplishments tangible.
Quantify your achievements (e.g., "boosted sales by 30%" or "managed a $2M budget").
Numbers help recruiters understand your impact.

7ï¸âƒ£ Use a Modern, ATS-Friendly Template
ğŸ“„ Why it matters: An ATS-friendly design ensures your resume gets seen.
Avoid graphics, images, or complicated tables.
Stick to clean, simple layouts that ATS software can easily parse.

Pro Tip: A great resume is your gateway to landing interviews. Invest time to polish it and consider professional services if needed.

post_html:
I often get referrals from colleagues in my network asking me to chat with someone who's going through a job transition. When I meet with them, I share this advice:

Get out of your own head. Whatever the reason for your transition, be confident in who you are. Don't start second-guessing yourself or the reasons for the change. Learn from the past when needed and move forward. Now is not the time for imposter syndrome.

Start by making a list of work that genuinely inspires you. About 70% of high-performing professionals find success by aligning their passion with their profession. What truly brings you joy at work?

Next, make a list of organizations you admire within the geography you want to work. Research these organizations looking for clues that relate to your list. This should include checking their websites, Glassdoor, and asking friends and colleagues. You may discover companies you didn't even know existed.

Start networking. The days of just applying for a job and hoping your resume gets picked are over. Begin by checking your admired organization's LinkedIn page for connections you know, or people who can introduce you to key contacts. Look at open roles that might interest you, but remember, new roles are created all the time when the right person shows up. Doing this can get your resume in front of the actual hiring manager.

Lastly, tell everyone you meet that you're looking for work â€“ even your dog groomer might know of an awesome role through one of their customers (to be clear, you want input from the dog parents, not the dog ğŸ˜Š).

All this will transform your job search from transactional to transformational. Position yourself as a strategic solution, not just a candidate. Organizations invest in professionals who solve complex challenges.

Remember: Companies hire potential, not just past achievements. Highlight your unique value and show how your skills can drive organizational success.

ğŸ… What tips do you have that have worked for you in your search?


hashtag#ProfessionalDevelopment hashtag#CareerStrategy hashtag#NetworkingTips hashtag#Jobsearch

ğŸš¨ Are you looking for work? Applying to jobs and not hearing back?

Here are my Top 3 Tips for Job Seekers:
1. Crisp Resume
Write the value add that you bring to the table, your experience and expertise.
If you are a fresher, list out all the projects that you have done during your internship.

2. Alignment
Make sure that there is at least 70% overlap between your skills and what the hiring manager is looking for.

3. Certification is Good; Portfolio is Better
Nothing impresses more than the actual work (samples).
Your Portfolio, GitHub repo, Capstone projects, etc go a long way.


In the last 2 decades;
Conducted hundreds of interviews along with the hiring team;
I have appeared in 50+ interviews as a candidate;
Converted 20+ successfully.

Sharing what has worked for me over the years!
All the very best.


Hiring Managers,
If you are interviewing more than 20 candidates for a role, then STOP.
There is no perfect match, stop looking for one.

post_html:
I reviewed 4,000+ resumes last year. Hereâ€™s an anonymized Software Engineer resume. Let's roast it together â¡ï¸


Itâ€™s a good resume, but small changes can double their chances of landing interviews.

Recruiters spend 6 (!) seconds per resume, so the first impression matters.


Some of the most common mistakes and what to do instead:

OVERDESIGNING

âŒ Using progress bars, decorative elements, overdesigning

âœ… Keeping design as simple as possible


DESIGNING FOR READING, NOT SCANNING

âŒ Long paragraphs, less bulleted lists

âœ… Bulleted lists, using the bold or italic font to highlight some experiences


SHORT EXPERIENCE DESCRIPTIONS

âŒ Focusing too much on education, certifications, etc.

âœ… Experience description should take up to 70-80% of the resume


NO COMPANY DESCRIPTIONS

Use These copy-and-paste AI Prompts to Craft a Standout Cover Letter ğŸ‘‡

Make a lasting impression. Get more interviews. Land your dream role!

Try these 7 prompts to supercharge your cover letter:

âœ‰ï¸ Prompt 1: Personalized Opening Creator
Draft an engaging introduction tailored to [Company Name]. Highlight recent initiatives, values, or achievements. Create three variations: one focused on cultural alignment, one on innovation, and one on solving key challenges. Include "connection strength" and "engagement rating" for each. Limit to 75 words. My resume: [Paste Resume]. Company insights: [Paste Research].

âœ‰ï¸ Prompt 2: Qualification Alignment Mapper
Analyze [Job Title] requirements and match them to my qualifications in a table format with columns for 'Requirement', 'My Experience', and 'Proof of Success'. Add match strength percentages and key talking points. Identify three standout factors that differentiate me. My resume: [Paste Resume]. Job description: [Paste Job Description].

âœ‰ï¸ Prompt 3: Success Story Crafter
Generate three impactful success stories tailored to [Target Role] using the Challenge-Action-Result framework. Focus on measurable outcomes and business impact. Rate each story's strength and memorability. Keep each story concise (50 words max). My resume: [Paste Resume]. Job description: [Paste Job Description].

âœ‰ï¸ Prompt 4: Experience-Needs Connector
Create a table linking [Job Title] priorities with my skills and accomplishments. Use columns for 'Company Need', 'My Contribution', and 'Supporting Evidence'. Assign relevance and impact scores for each entry. Limit entries to 15 words each. My resume: [Paste Resume]. Job description: [Paste Job Description].

âœ‰ï¸ Prompt 5: Culture Fit Demonstrator
Identify core values and cultural traits from [Company Name]. Write evidence-based statements showing alignment with their mission and ethos. Present in a table with 'Company Value', 'My Experience', and 'Specific Example'. Include authenticity ratings for each match. Company insights: [Paste Research]. My resume: [Paste Resume].

âœ‰ï¸ Prompt 6: Distinct Value Communicator
Write a compelling second paragraph showcasing my unique strengths for [Role]. Develop three versions emphasizing problem-solving, innovation, or team-building skills. Include measurable results and forward-looking statements. Rate differentiation level for each version. My resume: [Paste Resume]. Job description: [Paste Job Description].

âœ‰ï¸ Prompt 7: Passion Statement Builder
Craft an enthusiastic third paragraph expressing excitement about the opportunity at [Company Name]. Incorporate industry knowledge and company-specific insights. Create tailored versions for startups, corporate environments, or growth-stage businesses. Evaluate sincerity signals for each version. My resume: [Paste Resume]. Company insights: [Paste Research].

post_html:
I bet most job seekers have fallen for these 5 resume myths at some point.


------------------------------------


Let's clear the fog! ğŸ¯

ğŸš« Myth 1: Resumes Should ONLY be One Page

Nope! Freshers, keep it short. But for experienced folks, focus on relevance. Feature what matters to the recruiter, even if it goes beyond one page.

ğŸš« Myth 2: Your Resume Should Be All Pretty and Flashy

Totally wrong! Your resume isn't an art project. Keep it clean and pro. Make the format easy on the eyes, not an eye-catcher.

ğŸš« Myth 3: Your Resume Should Have a Photo of You

False alarm! Unless they ask, skip the photo. It's a distraction, not a necessity. Save that space for something valuable.

ğŸš« Myth 4: Only Paid Experience Counts

Not true! If you're a fresher with internships and projects, they matter. No need for paid gigs right away. Your skills and efforts count too.

ğŸš« Myth 5: You Need to Add an Objective Section

Nah, they're kinda useless. Everyone wants to apply their skills. Instead, use that space wisely. Highlight your key skills and results â€“ make it count.


-----------------------------------------


Remember, stay informed and keep your knowledge fresh.

Comment if you know more resume myths! ğŸ’¬
